body.p: Alpar-Vajk Kramer (Medias), Florian Luca (Bielefeld)

Abstract. In this note, we collect a few facts about Heron triangles. For example, we show that there exist infinitely many pairs of incongruent Heron triangles having the same area and semiperimeter and that there is no Heron triangle having the radius of the circumscribed circle a power of 2 or a power of a prime number ğ‘pp such that ğ‘11modâ€…12pâ‰¡11â¢(modâ¢â€…12)p\equiv 11(\mathrm{m}\mathrm{o}\mathrm{d}\ 12) .
AMS Classification Number: llD61, 11D7211â¢Dâ¢7211\mathrm{D}72
1. Introduction

A Heron triangle is a triangle having the lengths of all its three sides as well as its aria integers. There are still several nice open problems concerning Heron triangles and the book of Richard Guy 5 contains a few such. For example (see D21 in 5), it is not known if there exist Heron triangles having all medians integers. It is also not known if there exist Pythagorean triples whose products are equal, i.e. if there is a solution of the equation

in nonzero integers ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘¤(x,y,z,w)(x,\ y,\ z,\ w) . Another open problem due to Harborth and Kemnitz (see 6 and 7) asks to find all Heron triangles whose sides are members of the Fibonacci sequence. It is easy to see that such triangles have to be isosceles but the only known example is the one of sides 5â€…5â€…8(5,â€…5,â€…8)(5,\ 5,\ 8) . Finally, we also mention that another open problem from 5 (see D18) asks for the existence of a perfect cuboid, i.e. a rectangular box with all edges, face diagonals and main diagonal integers. Incidentally, in 8, one of us showed that the existence of a perfect cuboid is equivalent with the existence of a Heron triangle whose sides are perfect squares and whose angle bisectors are rationals but it seems by no means easier to decide whether such a triangle exists. On the positive side of things, we mention that in 9 we found all Heron triangles whose sides are prime powers. Except for the Pythagorean triple 3â€…4â€…5(3,â€…4,â€…5)(3,\ 4,\ 5) they are in one-to-one correspondence with the Fermat primes larger than 3.

In what follows, we denote by ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘a,b,ca,b,c the sides of a triangle and by ğ´AA its aria. We also use ğ‘ ğ‘Ÿs,rs,r and ğ‘…RR for the semiperimeter, radius of the inscribed circle and radius of the circumscribed circle, respectively. In this note, we collect a few remarks on Heron triangles.
2. Pairs of Heron triangles with the same area

In this section, we point out that there are infinitely many pairs of incongruent Heron triangles having the same area. A particularly pretty parametric family of such pairs of Heron triangles can be obtained using the familiar Fibonacci sequence. Recall that the Fibonacci sequence subscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ‘›0(Fn)nâ‰¥0(F_{n})_{n\geq 0} is the sequence having the initial values formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¹00subscriptğ¹11F0=0,F1=1F_{0}=0,F_{1}=1 and satisfying the recurrence
for all integers ğ‘›0nâ‰¥0n\geq 0. We have the following result.

Proposition 1. Let ğ‘›1nâ‰¥1n\geq 1 be a positive integer. Then, there exists a pair of incongruent Heron triangles having ğ´subscriptğ¹ğ‘›subscriptğ¹ğ‘›1subscriptğ¹ğ‘›2subscriptğ¹ğ‘›3subscriptğ¹ğ‘›4subscriptğ¹ğ‘›5A=Fnâ¢Fn+1â¢Fn+2â¢Fn+3â¢Fn+4â¢Fn+5.A=F_{n}F_{n+1}F_{n+2}F_{n+3}F_{n+4}F_{n+5}.

3. More pairs of Heron triangles with the same area and perimeter

We searched for pairs of incongruent Heron triangles having not only the same area ğ´AA but also the same semiperimeter ğ‘ ss. One such example is the pair of triangles of sides 24â€…35â€…53(24,â€…35,â€…53)(24,\ 35,\ 53) and 48â€…14â€…50(48,â€…14,â€…50)(48,\ 14,\ 50) both having the same area ğ´336A=336A=336 and semiperimeter ğ‘ 56s=56s=56. Based on this example, we found an infinite parametric family of pairs of such triangles. This family is given explicitely as follows.
Proposition 2. Letğ‘¡1tâ‰¥1t\geq 1be any positive integer and letğ‘‡ğ‘¡Tâ¢(t)T(t)andsubscriptğ‘‡1ğ‘¡T1â¢(t)T_{1}(t)be the triangles of sides

and the same area, namely

Remark 2. We point out that the statement of Proposition 2 is nontrivial in the sens that the pairs subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡1ğ‘¡ğ‘¡1(Tâ¢(t),T1â¢(t))tâ‰¥1(T(t),\ T_{1}(t))_{t\geq 1} are not similar fn different values of ğ‘¡t.t. Indeed, since the two Heron triangles 24â€…35â€…53(24,â€…35,â€…53)(24,\ 35,\ 53) and 48â€…14â€…50(48,â€…14,â€…50)(48,\ 14,\ 50) have the same area and semiperimeter, it follows that the two Heron triangles 24ğ‘¡â€…35ğ‘¡â€…53ğ‘¡(24â¢t,â€…35â¢t,â€…53â¢t)(24t,\ 35t,\ 53t) and 48ğ‘¡â€…14ğ‘¡â€…50ğ‘¡(48â¢t,â€…14â¢t,â€…50â¢t)(48t,\ 14t,\ 50t) have the same area and semiperimeter as well for any positive integer ğ‘¡tt. Of course, this is not a very interesting family. To see why the statement of Propositon 2 is non-trivial, notice first that by formula (8), ğ‘cc is always odd. In particular, gcdğ‘ğ‘ğ‘gcdğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§gcdâ¢(a,b,c)=gcdâ¢(x,y,z)\mathrm{g}\mathrm{c}\mathrm{d}(a,\ b,\ c)=\mathrm{g}\mathrm{c}\mathrm{d}(x,\ y% ,\ z) fn the triangle ğ‘‡ğ‘¡Tâ¢(t)T(t) . But now, by formula (14) and the substitutions from the proof of Proposition 2, one has

In particular, the Heron triangle ğ‘‡ğ‘¡Tâ¢(t)T(t) is always primitive. Unfortunately, the triangle subscriptğ‘‡1ğ‘¡T1â¢(t)T_{1}(t) is never primitive as it can be immediately noticed from formula (15).

Our Proposition 2 provides an infinite family of pairs of Heron triangles having the same aria and semiperimeter but these are not all of them. For example, the pairs of Heron triangles fragments{fragments(51,52,101){(51,52,101)\{(51,52,101) , fragments(17,â€…87,â€…100orfragments{fragments(20,21,29),fragments(17,25,28)}(17,â€…87,â€…100or{(20,21,29),(17,25,28)}(17,\ 87,\ 100\ \mathrm{o}\mathrm{r}\ \{(20,21,29),\ (17,25,28)\} n fragments{fragments(17,28,39){(17,28,39)\{(17,28,39) , fragmentsfragments(12,â€…35,â€…37)}(12,â€…35,â€…37)}(12,\ 35,\ 37)\} have the same areas and semiperimeters but they are not particular instances of our general family given by formulae (8) and (9). We conclude this section by suggesting the following problem.
Problem. Find the largestğ‘˜kkfor which there existğ‘˜kkmutually incongruent Heron triangles having the same area and semiperimeter.
4. Heron triangles whose area has prescribed prime factors
In this section, we take a look at the prime factns of the area of a Heron triangle.
Let ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} be a finite set of primes and let

That is, for a fixed finite set of prime numbers ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}, we let ğ‘†SS be the set of all positive integers whose prime factors belong to fragmentsâ€²Pâ€²P\prime P. We first investigate the problem of finding all the Heron triangles having ğ´ğ‘†AâˆˆSA\in S. We should first notice that if assignğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘T:=(a,b,c)T:=(a,\ b,\ c) is a Heron triangle having ğ´ğ‘†AâˆˆSA\in S, then assignğ‘‘gcdğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘†d:=gcdâ¢(a,b,c)âˆˆSd:=\mathrm{g}\mathrm{c}\mathrm{d}(a,\ b,\ c)\in S as well. Hence, it suffices to restrict our attention to primitive Heron triangles assignğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘T:=(a,b,c)T:=(a,\ b,\ c) . Our first result in this direction is the following.
Proposition 3. Letğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}be a fixed finite set of primes and letğ‘†SSbe given by formula (21). Then, there exist only finitely many primitive Heron triangles havingğ´ğ‘†AâˆˆS.A\in S.

Proof of Proposition 3. Assume that assignğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘T:=(a,b,c)T:=(a,\ b,\ c) satisfies ğ´ğ‘†AâˆˆSA\in S. Write again formulae-sequenceğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘¦ğ‘ ğ‘x=s-a,y=s-bx=s-a,y=s-b and ğ‘§ğ‘ ğ‘z=s-cz=s-c. Since ğ‘‡TT is primitive, it follows that gcdğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§1gcdâ¢(x,y,z)=1\mathrm{g}\mathrm{c}\mathrm{d}(x,\ y,\ z)=1. Now the containment ğ´ğ‘†AâˆˆSA\in S together with the fact that

imply

Equation (23) is known as an ğ‘†SS-unit equation and it has only finitely many solutions satisfying gcdğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§1gcdâ¢(x,y,z)=1\mathrm{g}\mathrm{c}\mathrm{d}(x,\ y,\ z)=1 by a result of Evertse (see 4). Unfortunately,the proof of Evertse from 4 concerning the finiteness of the number of solutions of equation (23) is not effective. In particular, this means that, apriori, there is no algorithm which for a given fragmentsâ€²Pâ€²P\prime P will allow one to list all primitive Heron triangles having ğ´ğ‘†AâˆˆSA\in S. It is also known and easy to prove that if ğ´AA is the area of a Heron triangle, then 6 fragments|A|A|A. In particular, if one starts with a set fragmentsâ€²Pâ€²P\prime P of primes and one wants any Heron triangles at all with area ğ´ğ‘†AâˆˆSA\in S, then one should allow 2, fragments3â€²P3âˆˆâ€²P3\in\prime P. In light of these remarks and of Proposition 3, it makes sens to ask if one can determine all the Heron triangles having ğ´ğ‘†AâˆˆSA\in S when fragmentsâ€²Pfragments{2â€²P={2\prime P=\{2, 3 }}\}. Here is the result.

Proposition 4. Assume that ğ‘‡TT is a primitive Heron triangle having ğ‘†â‹…superscript2ğ›¼superscript3ğ›½S=2Î±â‹…3Î²S=2^{\alpha}\cdot 3^{\beta} for some non-negative integers ğ›¼Î±\alpha and ğ›½Î²\beta. Then, ğ‘‡TT is congruent to one of the following 10 Heron triangles

Proof of Proposition 4. By equations (22) and (23), it follows that every primitive Heron triangle assignğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘T:=(a,b,c)T:=(a,\ b,\ c) having ğ´â‹…superscript2ğ›¼superscript3ğ›½A=2Î±â‹…3Î²A=2^{\alpha}\cdot 3^{\beta} can be found by first solving equation
ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘¤x+y+z=wx+y+z=w,

where gcdğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§1gcdâ¢(x,y,z)=1\mathrm{g}\mathrm{c}\mathrm{d}(x,\ y,\ z)=1, the prime factors of ğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,yx,y and ğ‘§zz are in the set {2, 3} subject to the additional restriction that xyzw is a square. One can easily solve the above equation (even without the restriction that xyzw is a square) using the results of Mo De Ze and R. Tijdeman from 3 (based on Bakerâ€™s method) in a matter of seconds on a PCPC\mathrm{P}\mathrm{C}, also in the case when the primes 2, 3 are replaced by any pair of primes not exceeding 200. We also point out that equation (25) was solved by elementary means by Leo J. Alex and Lnraine Foster in the series of papers 1 and 2 even when the set of primes {2, 3} is replaced by the larger set of primes {2, 3, 5}. One can now look at all such solutions listed in 1 and 2 and conclude that the only Heron triangles satisfying the hypothesis of Proposition 4 are indeed the ones listed at (24). We omit further details.

Remark 3. In the upcoming paper 10, we show that if fragmentsâ€²Pâ€²P\prime P is a given set of finitely many prime numbers, then there exist only finitely many primitive Heron triangles having ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘†aâ¢bâ¢câˆˆSabc\in S. Although the full result is not effective, it can be made effective in some instances. Fn example, in 10, we find all primitive Heron triangles having the property that the maximal prime divisor of ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘aâ¢bâ¢cabc does not exceed 11.
5. Heron triangles with prescribed ğ‘Ÿrr or ğ‘…RR

In this section, we leave the issues concerning areas of Heron triangles and we look at existence results fn Heron triangles with given integer ğ‘Ÿrr or ğ‘…RR. Our main results here are the following.
Proposition 5. Let ğ‘˜1kâ‰¥1k\geq 1 be a positive integer. Then, there exists a Heron triangle ğ‘‡TT having ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜r=k.r=k.
Proof of Proposition 5. We use the notations ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§x,y,zx,y,z, etc. from the preceeding sections. Since ğ‘Ÿğ´ğ‘ r=A/sr=A/s, it suffices to show that the equation
has a positive solution ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§x,y,zx,y,z. We choose ğ‘§1z=1z=1 and equation (26) becomes
or
or
ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘¦1ğ‘¦superscriptğ‘˜2x=k2â¢(y+1)y-k2x=\displaystyle\frac{k^{2}(y+1)}{y-k^{2}}.

Clearly, one may now choose ğ‘¦superscriptğ‘˜21y=k2+1y=k^{2}+1 and then formula (27) tells us that ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘˜42superscriptğ‘˜2x=k4+2â¢k2x=k^{4}+2k^{2} Hence, the triangle of sides formulae-sequenceğ‘superscriptğ‘˜22ğ‘superscriptğ‘˜42superscriptğ‘˜21a=k2+2,b=k4+2â¢k2+1a=k^{2}+2,b=k^{4}+2k^{2}+1 and ğ‘superscriptğ‘˜43superscriptğ‘˜21c=k4+3â¢k2+1c=k^{4}+3k^{2}+1 is a Heron triangle with ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜r=k.r=k.

While Proposition 5 shows that one can construct Heron triangles of arbitrary integer radius ğ‘Ÿrr, this is no longer true if one replaces ğ‘Ÿrr by ğ‘…RR, but it is almost true. That is, we have the following result.
Proposition 6. 1. The set of positive integers ğ‘˜1kâ‰¥1k\geq 1 for which there exists a Heron triangle having ğ‘…ğ‘˜R=kR=k has asymptotic density 1.
2. There is no Heron triangle having ğ‘…RR a power of 2 or a power of a prime number ğ‘pp such that ğ‘11pâ‰¡11p\equiv 11 (mod 12) .

Proof of Proposition 6, Part 1. Let ğ‘pp be a prime which is congruent to 1 modulo 4. Since ğ‘pp is a sum of two squares, we can write ğ‘superscriptğ‘¢2superscriptğ‘£2p=u2+v2p=u^{2}+v^{2}. Then, the triangle of sides

is Heron and has ğ‘…superscriptğ‘¢2superscriptğ‘£2ğ‘R=u2+v2=pR=u^{2}+v^{2}=p. Indeed, this follows immediately from the fact that the above triangle is right angled, so its ğ‘…RR is equal to half of its hypothenuse. It is now clear that if ğ‘˜kk is an arbitrary positive integer which is a multiple of ğ‘pp, then there exists a Heron triangle of radius ğ‘…ğ‘˜R=kR=k. To see this, it suffices to consider the triangle which is similar to the triangle given by (28) but whose sides are ğ‘˜ğ‘k/pk/p times longer. The conclusion of 1 follows now from the fact that almost every positive integer is divisible by a prime ğ‘1pâ‰¡1p\equiv 1(mod 4).

Before proving Part 2 of Proposition 6, we need to make some considerations concerning arbitrary Heron triangles. Assume that assignğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘T:=(a,b,c)T:=(a,\ b,\ c) is a Heron triangle of area ğ´AA and semiperimeter ğ‘ ss and let again formulae-sequenceğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘formulae-sequenceğ‘¦ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘§ğ‘ ğ‘x=s-a,y=s-b,z=s-cx=s-a,y=s-b,z=s-c. The following Lemma turns out to be useful.
Lemma. (i.) One of the numbers ğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘¤u,v,wu,v,w is odd and one of them is even. In particular, ğ‘”ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ·gâ¢câ¢dâ¢(a,b,c)=D.gcd(a,\ b,\ c)=D.
(ii.) If ğ‘pp is an odd prime such that fragmentsp|gcdfragments(uv,uw)p|gcd(u+v,u+w)p|gcd(u+v,\ u+w) , then ğ‘1ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘‘4pâ‰¡1â¢(mâ¢oâ¢dâ¢4)p\equiv 1(mod4) .

Proof of the Lemma. (i). Since ğ‘”ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘¤1gâ¢câ¢dâ¢(u,v,w)=1gcd(u,\ v,\ w)=1, it follows that at least one of the numbers ğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘¤u,v,wu,v,w is odd. Proof of Proposition 6, Part 2. Formulae (46) and (47) show that each one of the last two numbers of list (38) are strictly larger than 1 (they are each a sum of two positive integers). In particular, this rules out the possibility that ğ‘…RR is a power of 2 (compare to list (39)). Equation (54) is impossible because ğ‘qq is a power of a prime ğ‘pp with ğ‘3ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘‘4pâ‰¡3â¢(mâ¢oâ¢dâ¢4)p\equiv 3(mod4) . When the second number of list (38) is 4, then one uses formula (46) to conclude that the only possibilities are

The case 2â€…2(2,â€…2)(2,\ 2) above can be ruled out easily by considerations modulo 2. In the remaining two cases, an analysis similar to the one done above when the second number fiom list (38) was 2, leads to a representation of ğ‘qq of the fnm ğ‘superscriptğ›¾23superscriptğ›¿2q=Î³2+3â¢Î´2q=\gamma^{2}+3\delta^{2} which is impossible because ğ‘qq is a power of a prime ğ‘pp with ğ‘11modâ€…12pâ‰¡11â¢(modâ¢â€…12)p\equiv 11(\mathrm{m}\mathrm{o}\mathrm{d}\ 12) . We do not give further details. Proposition 6 is therefore completely proved.

Remark 4. The above proof of the second assertion of Proposition 6 does much mne than simply prove it. A careful investigation of the arguments employed in it show, fn example, that if ğ‘pp is a prime number such that ğ‘5ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘‘12pâ‰¡5â¢(mâ¢oâ¢dâ¢12)p\equiv 5(mod12) , then there exists a unique Heron triangle having ğ‘…ğ‘R=pR=p, which is a Pythagnean triangle. In particular, the triangle 6â€…8â€…10(6,â€…8,â€…10)(6,\ 8,\ 10) is the unique Heron triangle with ğ‘…5R=5.R=5.
